highlighted_text:
greatest impact was the Call for Participation section.

The CFP section of TWIR is a list of good first issues and issues that maintainers need extra help on. As I said earlier, I’d wanted to contribute to open source for years but I had never succeeded in finding an opportunity that actually got me to engage.

The weekly list of friendly first issues I could get involved in made it trivial to find issues that were available to work on and approachable for someone new to the code base. I didn’t have to do anything now to find work, it just walked up to me on its own whenever I went to read the news.

So I got involved, I did a minor issue on rustc, just cleaning up some test code, and all of a

sudden the problem space wasn’t so scary anymore.
but I’m really shy around people I don’t know, so I mostly kept to myself

our wonderful meetup organizer, walked up to me, unprompted, and asked “Hey, you’re Jane right?”. I was shocked, how the heck did Manish know who I was? It didn’t feel as though I’d done anything worthy of notice, and yet here he was asking for me by name

The big take away here is that meetup are an amazing way to get involved and to feel involved in a community. There are so many amazing rustaceans that go to all these meetups and conferences, so they’re a great opportunity to meet and learn from amazing people. If you’re not already going to meetups, you should seriously consider starting.
Speaking of complaining about features I wanted, Manish fundamentally changed how I approach open source work.
The solution here ended up being to know my limit and to break my tasks up into smaller more approachable tasks.
minor” features that I had been wanting for ages.
Any time I mentioned a feature I wanted she told me to open an issue
Now I have a nicely organized list of every issue that integrates seamlessly all the different repos I’m working with and I can share this list with people if they’re looking for things to work on
convinced me to write that await blog post and announce it on Twitter so he could retweet it.

I would often go to him to complain about features I wanted that didn’t exist or talk about the bikeshed of the moment, in this case await syntax. He encouraged me to write a little blog post explaining why I was hoping for postfix macro to be the syntax of choice.

The real difference is how you interact with people on Twitter vs Reddit. Discussion on Reddit is better for impersonal discussion, where as Twitter tends to encourage more personal discourse. It’s much easier to make friends and have consistent interactions with people on Twitter than it is on Reddit, which is exactly what you need if you want to participate in a community.

Case in point, I’ve made dozens of rust friends on Twitter, many of whom are in this room today, and I’m pretty sure I’ve made 0 friends on Reddit. So if you’re looking to make some rust friends and get more involved in the community, consider using Twitter and following every rustacean you can find.
Hey I see you’re active in the Rust OSS community, would you be interested in talking about any of it? COGoldRust
Navigating The Rust OSS Community | New to Me Things like J and go out of your way to find qualified speakers and encourage them to take the leap.

Use twitter to make friends in the rust community.

Reach out to people, it makes a huge difference.
